DOC.HEAD: Signing Santa Makes Christmas Complete for Deaf Children
DOC.TEXT: The dozens of giggling children lined up to see Santa Claus at the shopping mall fell silent and watched intently as 10-year-old Jeannette Johnson climbed into his lap and started talking with him. Jeannette and Santa used sign language to speak. Jeannette is deaf, making Bruce Partridge one of the few Santas to whom she can tell her wishes. With hands fluttering, she told him what presents she wanted _ including a guitar. ``If it's very loud I can feel it,'' she said. Using his white wool-gloved hands, Santa promised to stop by on Christmas Eve. ``Ho, ho, ho,'' doesn't exactly translate, so he made the sign for laughter, a kind of rotating motion from the belly. This is the third year that Partridge, a Kent County sheriff's deputy, has put his sign language talents to as St. Nick. ``Adults think it's such a small thing, but it's so important for kids to believe that Santa can sign, too,'' Partridge said. ``Deaf kids grow up in a hearing world, on the outside looking in. But they don't want pity; they want to participate. ... This is one way to show them it's OK to be deaf.'' Partridge, 36, began signing about five years ago to communicate with deaf relatives and because he occasionally dealt with deaf citizens on the job. Now a part-time interpreter at a local school district, Partridge and another Grand Rapids man began posing as Santas for an annual potluck dinner for deaf people a few years ago and ``decided that there were other deaf children in the area who might like to talk to Santa.'' While deaf children may miss out on the bell choirs and holiday music, Partridge believes that after seeing Santa, ``they go away happy that they can have Christmas, too.''
